lexUnit.name: perfect.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: cause development at the highest standard.

sentence.text: A clinic has perfected a Â£3,500 technique to help make them fathers again .
He had perfected the technique of not being noticed to a fine art .
The canny Taiwanese have perfected the technique of ` shadow dancing " .
Using a technique perfected by medical artists , they hope to be able to build up a picture of what the princess would have looked like twenty centuries ago .
The technology for a reed bed was pioneered in Germany 20 years ago , and has been perfected by ICI over the last two years .
While you have been perfecting your French , I have been bettering my English .
You 've already perfected the tests . "
He had perfected a glib story .
But they only started to perfect it at the end of the nineteenth century .
Fred had perfected it during his ten years at the school .

This stage culmin - ated in the massive reorganization of General Electric in the early 1950s , an action that perfected the model most big businesses around the world ( including Japanese organizations ) still follow .
But we have now perfected a unique product . "
Lizzie liked perfecting this pretty piece of domestic felicity .
Muirhead perfected the electrical standards of capacity , which he practically established and afterwards handed over to the National Physical Laboratory .
No pacifist method has yet been perfected in this country to counter Hitler .
The Arsenal machine had been perfected , and the 1930 Cup triumph was to usher in a glorious future .
Their method has been perfected after years of experience dealing with female victims of violence .
` The idea was first perfected in America .
I practise perfecting things I can almost already play .
It was a trick he had long ago perfected .
Ferreting has been perfected to the point where it does a thorough job .
It was another pattern that would be expanded , developed and perfected with ferocity over the coming 15 years .
